content.description:
This route is long, alluring, and sure to please! In fact, it is the longest single pitch on the Redwood Coast [edit: that honor now belonging to Love and War]. Warm up with a relaxing slab on the far left side of the wall before launching into the endless headwall. The 20’ crux comes just above a small ledge and has three closely spaced fixed draws for safety. Once pulling onto the crux, two big crosses land a hidden right hand fingerlock to clip the second fixed draw. A few feet of laybacking lead to the third fixed draw where you will set your feet and reach high for a mega-jug. This mega-jug makes a much-needed seated rest before starting the 5.10+ marathon to the top. A small ledge at the anchor makes belaying your partner comfortable while they haul a second rope.

If a hold feels sharp or uncomfortable, there is always a better one nearby

! Don't miss this one, you and your partner are sure to have a good time!
content.protection:
21 bolts, (3 are fixed draws), and 2 bolt rap anchor.

Pay attention to the rope path on the lower half and use plenty of slings (12” and 24") to prevent rope drag. Experienced trad climbers should know which bolts to clip medium or long. With 4-5 slings in the right place, and at least six 12" draws (folded over sling), the rope runs 100% smooth to the top!
content.location: Far left side of the Main Tower, at the base of an easy slab. Belay from the trail.

content.description: Incredible climbing on great rock with many, many 5.11 cruxes. Starts off just under vertical then slowly steepens and the real climbing starts(5th bolt). Follow the bolts slightly left through sustained 5.11+ ground with a few unsatisfactory rests, topped by a heartbreaking bulge. Climb vertical 5.10+ for another 70ft to the anchor. No move is harder than 11c, but with a bunch of draws and 2 ropes hanging off you, not to mention a wicked pump, it feels damn hard!
content.protection: 20 bolts, 2 bolt anchor. A few long draws help, but not totally necessary. 2 ropes needed to get off. Figure out your cleaning/lowering system beforehand, you won't be able to see or hear your belayer from the anchor.
content.location: Middle of the Main Tower. Should see the first bolt about 10ft off the ground. The bolt line heads slightly left up nice yellow rock before it disappears over a dark bulge.

content.description:
Love and War is a freakin' awesome 190' mega-pitch of consistent 11a to a two-move 12a crux 180' off the deck.

After eight bolts of Bomb Shelter, fork left, then avoid drifting farther left into Golden Shower (or do drift left if you want to rig a top rope on Golden Shower). Once out of view of your belayer, you can rest on a short section of 5.7 before starting up a long and lonely 5.11- headwall (very well protected). At 180', you'll clip a bolt above your head then scratch your head at the WTF crux. The crux move actually isn't all that hard... once you find the hidden hold. The catch though is, finding that hidden hold on the onsight is damn hard!

If for whatever reason you need to bail, you can fix your line to a bolt, rap the line, then scramble up around the back with another rope and rap down from the summit off a bolted anchor. But, the bolts are close enough together you should be able to bumble your way up it with a stiffy draw.

Five slings are adequate to eliminate rope drag, though you'll appreciate using a lightweight rope! The bolts that need slings marked with tape wrapped on the hanger. Belay your second up from a nice ledge on top, then make two rappels with one rope (hitting the Golden Shower anchor on the way down).

Interesting route featuring a few cruxes and a variety of styles.  Layback a wide crack-feature created by a huge detached block, then pull a juggy roof at the top of the block.  The angle kicks back for a couple of bolts, then gets steeper again.  The crux comes right after the obvious break, making a couple of long reaches to good pinches - make sure to look down and get your feet set, or this might feel considerably harder.  Finish up blocky jugs.
content.location: Wide crack to face on the right side of the Main Tower.

content.description: Golden Shower is an unforgettable classic that seemed to have been forgotten in time. It is very rarely repeated, though perhaps not for long. Climb slab, to vertical, to bulges with some really unique holds. The climbing is varied; a little technical, a little burly, and very exciting with a growing pump. Just after the crux, sit on a ledge to recoup, then enjoy the victory lap of three bolts of 5.8-5.10 to the top.
content.location: Tucked away between some trees with a blue-stone start into a golden streak.

content.description:
Steep climbing with a low crux, followed by big moves between big holds.

Clip the first 2 bolts of "Ground Control", milk the stem rest, then head right through a short but burly crux on an undercut bulge. From here, follow overhanging jugs to a second, easier crux establishing yourself on the less-than-vertical headwall.
content.location: Far right side of the Main Tower.

content.description:
Looooong route on the Main Tower. The technical crux comes at about 40' where the wall steepens...head left into the vague dihedral, generally staying left for the next few bolts.  The endurance crux will come for most at the very top, between the last bolt and the anchors.

This route lives up to its name, and some sections are super sharp. Would be a 4-star route otherwise.
content.protection: 12 bolts, anchors. Anchors currently are hangers with bail biners...if you head up this rig, consider adding some quicklinks or chains, or suffer the consequences of an extremely twisted rope.

content.description:
Corner to overhanging face to slightly less-than-vertical finish on killer rock.

Climb a huge detached block to a high first bolt, up a corner, then cut left.  The majority of the route follows the path of least resistance up a shallow, overhanging dihedral with mostly huge holds to the left of the bolt line.  The crux is probably pulling the small bulge past the 8th bolt, it's a little harder if you head straight up and a little easier if you head right.
content.location: Right side of Main Tower - first route to the left of the wide crack start to Ground Control.
